facts.text: Three appellants were tried by the Additional Sessions Judge at Amritsar and found guilty of murdering Darshan Singh and Achhar Singh and sentenced to transportation for life.

anchor.surface_text: The three appellants were tried by the Additional Sessions Judge at Amritsar and found guilty of having murdered two persons named Darshan Singh and Achhar Singh and sentenced to transportation for life.

facts.text: High Court of Punjab upheld their conviction and sentence and granted certificate under article 134(1)(c) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Punjab upheld their conviction and sentence and granted them a certificate under article 134 1  c of the Constitution that the case is a fit one for appeal to this Court.

facts.text: On the evening of 16th December, 1948, a little before sunset, Achhar Singh went to the house of Inder Singh in village Dalam for getting paddy husked.

anchor.surface_text: On the evening of 16th December, 1948, a little before sunset, Achhar Singh, one of the murdered persons, went to the house of one Inder Singh in village Dalam for getting paddy husked.

facts.text: Darshan Singh came to Dalam from Amritsar the same evening and went to Inder Singh's house.

anchor.surface_text: Achhar Singhs brother, Darshan Singh, who was working as a driver at Amritsar, came to Dalam from Amritsar the same evening, and, on learning to know from his father that Achhar Singh had gone to Inder Singhs house, he also went there.

facts.text: While the two brothers were returning home, they were attacked by the three appellants and two of their relatives in a lane adjoining Inder Singh’s house.

anchor.surface_text: while the two brothers were returning home, they were attacked by the three appellants and two of their relatives in a lane adjoining Inder Singhs house.

facts.text: The five assailants armed with deadly weapons inflicted injuries on the two victims resulting in their death then and there.

anchor.surface_text: The five assailants, who were armed with deadly weapons, inflicted a number of injuries on the two victims, as a result of which they died then and there.

facts.text: After the murder, appellants and companions tied the dead bodies in two kheses (wrappers) and took them to village Saleempura.

anchor.surface_text: After the murder, the appellants and their companions tied the two dead bodies in two kheses  wrappers  and took them to village Saleempura where two other persons, named Ajaib Singh and Banta Singh, joined them,

facts.text: Dead bodies were dismembered and thrown into Sakinala stream about five miles from village Dalam.

anchor.surface_text: and the dead bodies after being dismembered were thrown into a stream known as Sakinala at a place about five miles from village Dalam.

facts.text: Bela Singh, father of deceased, witnessed the occurrence but left village next morning two hours before sunrise and lodged FIR at 10 A.M.

anchor.surface_text: Bela Singh, father of the deceased persons, who was one of the persons who claims to have witnessed the occurrence, did not leave the village at night on account of fear, but he started about two hours before sunrise on the next morning and lodged the first information report at 10 A.M. at the nearest police station.

facts.text: Police officer arrived in Dalam shortly afterwards, investigation led to charge-sheet against seven persons including appellants.

anchor.surface_text: A police officer arrived in village Dalam shortly afterwards, and after investigation a charge-sheet was submitted against seven persons including the present appellants.

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted appellants and two others under section 302/149 IPC to transportation for life.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge who tried the accused, convicted the appellants and two other persons under section 302 read with section 149 of the Penal Code and sentenced them to transportation for life,

facts.text: Ajaib Singh convicted under 201/149 to 3 years RI, Banta Singh acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: and convicted Ajaib Singh under section 201 read with section 149 and sentenced him to three years R.I. Banta Singh, accused, was acquitted.

facts.text: Punjab High Court upheld conviction of present appellants and acquitted the remaining three.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the Punjab High Court upheld the conviction of the present appellants and acquitted the remaining three persons.

facts.text: In June 1947, Natha Singh, father of third appellant Swaran Singh, was murdered.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in June, 1947, Natha Singh, father of the third appellant, Swaran Singh, was murdered,

facts.text: Darshan Singh, Achhar Singh and Sulakhan Singh charged with Natha Singh's murder; Darshan acquitted, Achhar 1.5 years RI, Sulakhan 7 years RI.

anchor.surface_text: and Darshan Singh and Achhar Singh, the two murdered persons in the case before us, and their third brother, Sulakhan Singh, were charged with the murder of that person. As a result of the trial, Darshan Singh was acquitted and Achhar Singh was sentenced to 11/2 years R.I., while Sulakhan Singh was sentenced to 7 years R.I.

facts.text: Massa Singh arrested on 18th December 1948 wearing pyjama stained with human blood.

anchor.surface_text: The second appellant, Massa Singh, who was arrested on the 18th December, 1948, was wearing a pyjama stained with human blood.

facts.text: Swaran Singh arrested on 18th December 1948, on 19th December took police to locked haveli from which two blood-stained kheses recovered.

anchor.surface_text: The third appellant, Swaran Singh, who was arrested on the 18th December, 1948, took the police on the 19th December to his haveli which was locked, and, on opening it two kheses  wrappers  which were stained with human blood were recovered.

facts.text: Swaran Singh pointed out spot on way to Sakinala where blood-stained earth recovered.

anchor.surface_text: Swaran Singh pointed out a spot on the way to Saki- nala, where the two dead bodies were placed for a short time while they were being taken to Sakinala, and the police scrapped blood-stained earth from that spot.

facts.text: Swaran Singh led police to bank of Sakinala and pointed out trunk of Darshan Singh's body.

anchor.surface_text: He also led the police to the bank of Sakinala and pointed out the trunk of the body of Darshan Singh which was lying in the nala.

facts.text: Lachhman Singh arrested on 28th December 1948, pointed out dilapidated khola near Sakinala where blood-stained weapons recovered.

anchor.surface_text: Lachhman Singh, who was arrested on the 28th Decem- ber, 1948, pointed out a dilapidated khola near Sakinala where 3 spears, one kirpan and a datar, all stained with human blood, were recovered.

facts.text: Judgment of Sessions Judge in prior case delivered shortly before the present occurrence.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the Sessions Judge in that case was delivered shortly before the date of the present occurrence,

facts.text: Achhar Singh released on bail by appellate court and at large at time of occurrence.

anchor.surface_text: and it is common ground that Achhar Singh had been released on bail by the appellate court and was at large at that time.

facts.text: Eye-witnesses: Bela Singh, Inder Singh, Mst. Taro, Gurcharan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The direct evidence consists of the testimony of four eye-witnesses, namely, Bela Singh, father of the deceased, who claims to have gone to the scene of occurrence on hearing an outcry and to have witnessed the murderous assault on his sons Inder Singh and his wife, Mst. Taro, to whom the murdered persons had gone for getting paddy husked and who lived in a house adjoining the lane where the murder took place and Gurcharan Singh,

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on March 21, 1952 by FAZL ALl J.

anchor.surface_text: 1952. March 21. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by FAZL ALl J. --The three appellants were tried by the Additional Sessions Judge at Amritsar and found guilty of having murdered two persons named Darshan Singh and Achhar Singh and sentenced to transportation for life.
The High Court of Punjab upheld their conviction and sentence and granted them a certificate under article 134 1  c of the Constitution that the case is a fit one for appeal to this Court.

issues.text: Whether, in all the circumstances of the case, it would be proper not to rely upon the oral evidence implicating particular accused unless there is some circumstantial evidence to support it

anchor.surface_text: the learned Judges of the High Court, though they re- pelled most of the criticisms levelled against the witness- es, ultimately came to the conclusion that in all the circumstances  of the case  it would be proper not to rely upon the oral evidence implicating particular accused unless there is some circumstantial evidence to support it.

issues.text: Whether this Court should reassess the evidence or interfere with concurrent findings in a criminal appeal after sifting by the trial court and High Court

anchor.surface_text: Proceeding, however, upon the principles laid down by this court, circumscribing the scope of a criminal appeal after the case has been sifted by the trial court and the High Court, it seems to us that the question involved in the present appeal is a short and simple one.

issues.text: Whether the discoveries made at the instance of Swaran Singh are admissible in evidence under section 27 of the Indian Evidence Act when information was received from multiple accused

anchor.surface_text: The comment against the discoveries made at the instance of Swaran Singh was that they are not admissible in evidence under section 27 of the Indian Evidence Act, which provides-- When any fact is deposed to as discovered in consequence of information received from a person accused of an offence in the custody of a police officer,

arguments.claim: The facts of the prior murder case constituted an equally strong motive for the appellants being falsely implicated since the murder was committed in circumstances where murderers could not be seen or identified

anchor.surface_text: It was conceded before us by the learned counsel for the appellants that the facts stated above constituted a strong motive for the murder, but he also contended that they constituted an equally strong motive for the appellants being falsely implicated in case the murder was committed, as was suggested by him, in circumstances under which the murderers could not be seen or identified.

arguments.claim: Eye-witness evidence is consistent, reliable, and establishes that the five accused murdered the deceased, further proved by recoveries

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge, who heard the evidence, seems to have been impressed by the evidence of the eye- witnesses, and he has summed up his conclusion in these words -- This evidence was so consistent, so reliable, and of such nature that in my opinion it is definitely established that the five accused Lachhman Singh, Katha Singh, Massa, Singh, Charan Singh and Swaran Singh are proved to have actually murdered both Darshan Singh and Achhar Singh.

arguments.claim: Proper not to rely on oral evidence implicating particular accused unless supported by circumstantial evidence

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court, though they repelled most of the criticisms levelled against the witnesses, ultimately came to the conclusion that in all the circumstances of the case it would be proper not to rely upon the oral evidence implicating particular accused unless there is some circumstantial evidence to support it.

anchor.surface_text: The comment of the learned counsel for the appellants with regard to the blood-stained pyjama which was recovered from Massa Singh was, firstly, that it was not possible to gather from the evidence the extent of the blood stains, and secondly that it would be highly improbable that this accused person would be so reckless as to continue to wear a blood stained pyjama after having perpetrated the crime.

arguments.claim: Post-mortem finding of partially digested rice infers occurrence at night after evening meal, contradicting prosecution timeline

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellants pointed out that the doctor who performed the post-mortem examination of the corpses, found partially digested rice in the stomach of the two deceased persons, and he urged that from this it would be inferred that the occurrence must have taken place sometime at night after the deceased persons had taken their evening meals together.

arguments.claim: Corroboration required is not accomplice-type but circumstantial assurance for eye-witness evidence as prudence

anchor.surface_text: According to our reading of the judgment of the High Court, the learned Judges, who dealt with the case, did not condemn the oral evidence outright, but, as a matter of prudence and caution, they decided not to convict an accused person unless there were some circumstances to lend support to the evidence of the eye-witnesses with regard to him.

arguments.qualifiers: as a matter of prudence and caution

arguments.claim: Circumstantial evidence sufficiently corroborates oral evidence against each appellant per High Court standard

anchor.surface_text: Judged by this standard, which it was open to them to prescribe, it seems to us that the case of each of the appellants clearly fell within the rule which they had laid down for their own guidance.

holdings.text: Proceeding, however, upon the principles laid down by this court, circumscribing the scope of a criminal appeal after the case has been sifted by the trial court and the High Court, it seems to us that the question involved in the present appeal is a short and simple one.

anchor.surface_text: Proceeding, however, upon the principles laid down by this court, circumscribing the scope of a criminal appeal after the case has been sifted by the trial court and the High Court, it seems to us that the question involved in the present appeal is a short and simple one.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows established principles of this court limiting interference with factual findings after scrutiny by trial court and High Court.

holdings.text: According to our reading of the judgment of the High Court, the learned Judges, who dealt with the case, did not condemn the oral evidence outright, but, as a matter of prudence and caution, they decided not to convict an accused person unless there were some circumstances to lend support to the evidence of the eye-witnesses with regard to him. It is quite clear on reading the judgment that the corroboration which the learned judges required to satisfy themselves was not that kind of corroboration which one requires in the case of the evidence of an approver or an accomplice, but corroboration by some circumstances which would lend assurance to the evidence before them and satisfy them that the particular accused persons were really concerned in the murder of the deceased.

anchor.surface_text: According to our reading of the judgment of the High Court, the learned Judges, who dealt with the case, did not condemn the oral evidence outright, but, as a matter of prudence and caution, they decided not to convict an accused person unless there were some circumstances to lend support to the evidence of the eye-witnesses with regard to him. It is quite clear on reading the judgment that the corroboration which the learned judges required to satisfy themselves was not that kind of corroboration which one requires in the case of the evidence of an approver or an accomplice, but corroboration by some circumstances which would lend assurance to the evidence before them and satisfy them that the particular accused persons were really concerned in the murder of the deceased.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court required prudential corroboration by circumstances for eye-witness testimony implicating specific accused, distinct from accomplice rule; this standard is approved as open to courts.

holdings.text: Judged by this standard, which it was open to them to prescribe, it seems to us that the case of each of the appellants clearly fell within the rule which they had laid down for their own guidance.

anchor.surface_text: Judged by this standard, which it was open to them to prescribe, it seems to us that the case of each of the appellants clearly fell within the rule which they had laid down for their own guidance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Circumstantial evidence against each appellant (blood-stained pyjama for Massa Singh, recoveries for Swaran Singh, weapons for Lachhman Singh) provides required support to eye-witness testimony.

holdings.text: This criticism has been considered by the courts below, and it does not appear to us to be of such a nature as to affect the conclusion arrived at by them.

anchor.surface_text: This criticism has been considered by the courts below, and it does not appear to us to be of such a nature as to affect the conclusion arrived at by them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Criticisms of blood-stained pyjama evidence do not undermine lower courts' conclusions given limited scope of review.

holdings.text: It is sufficient to say that it is not the function of this court to reassess evidence and an argument on a point of fact which did not prevail with the courts below cannot avail the appellants in this court.

anchor.surface_text: It is sufficient to say that it is not the function of this court to reassess evidence and an argument on a point of fact which did not prevail with the courts below cannot avail the appellants in this court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects challenge to blood-stained weapons recovery as factual reassessment beyond this court's function.

holdings.text: For the purpose of this appeal, however, it is sufficient to state that even if the argument put forward on behalf of the appellants, which apparently found favour with the High Court, is correct, the discoveries made at the instance of Swaran Singh cannot be ruled out of consideration. It may be that several of the accused gave information to the police that the dead bodies could be recovered in the Sakinala... but such an indefinite information could not lead to any discovery unless the accused followed it up by conducting the police to the actual spot... From the evidence of the head constable as well as that of Bahadur Singh, it is quite clear that Swaran Singh led the police via Salimpura to a particular spot on Sakinala, and it was at his instance that blood-stained earth was recovered from a place outside the village, and he also pointed out the trunk of the body of Darshan Singh. The learned judges of the High Court were satisfied, as appears from their judgment, that his was the initial pointing out and therefore the case was covered even by the rule which, according to the counsel for the appellants, is the rule to be applied in the present case.

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose of this appeal, however, it is sufficient to state that even if the argument put forward on behalf of the appellants, which apparently found favour with the High Court, is correct, the discoveries made at the instance of Swaran Singh cannot be ruled out of consideration. It may be that several of the accused gave information to the police that the dead bodies could be recovered in the Sakinala, which is a stream running over several miles, but such an indefinite information could not lead to any discovery unless the accused followed it up by conducting the police to the actual spot where parts of the two bodies were recovered.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even under strict rule limiting to first information, Swaran Singh's specific and initial pointing out led to distinct discoveries, making them admissible under section 27.

holdings.text: as at present advised we are inclined to think that some of the cases relied upon by the learned counsel for the appellants have perhaps gone farther than is warranted by the language of section 27, and it may be that on a suitable occasion in future those cases may have to be reviewed.

anchor.surface_text: as at present advised we are inclined to think that some of the cases relied upon by the learned counsel for the appellants have perhaps gone farther than is warranted by the language of section 27, and it may be that on a suitable occasion in future those cases may have to be reviewed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior cases strictly limiting section 27 to only first accused's information may exceed statutory language when multiple accused provide independent information leading to discoveries.

holdings.text: The finding of the doctor therefore does not necessarily affect the prosecution case as to the time of occurrence.

anchor.surface_text: The finding of the doctor therefore does not necessarily affect the prosecution case as to the time of occurrence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-mortem evidence of partially digested rice inconclusive on timing due to variable digestion factors and lack of meal details.

anchor.surface_text: Judged by this standard, which it was open to them to prescribe, it seems to us that the case of each of the appellants clearly fell within the rule which they had laid down for their own guidance. The comment of the learned counsel for the appellants with regard to the blood-stained pyjama which was recovered from Massa Singh was, firstly, that it was not possible to gather from the evidence the extent of the blood stains, and secondly that it would be highly improbable that this ac- cused person would be so reckless as to continue to wear a blood stained pyjama after having perpetrated the crime.

For the purpose of this appeal, however, it is sufficient to state that even if the argument put forward on behalf of the appellants, which apparently found favour with the High Court, is correct, the discoveries made at the instance of Swaran Singh cannot be ruled out of consideration. It may be that several of the accused gave information to the police that the dead bodies could be recovered in the Sakinala, which is a stream running over several miles, but such an indefinite information could not lead to any discovery unless the accused followed it up by conducting the police to the actual spot where parts of the two bodies were recovered.

Judged by this standard, which it was open to them to prescribe, it seems to us that the case of each of the appellants clearly fell within the rule which they had laid down for their own guidance. The comment of the learned counsel for the appellants with regard to the blood-stained pyjama which was recovered from Massa Singh was, firstly, that it was not possible to gather from the evidence the extent of the blood stains, and secondly that it would be highly improbable that this ac- cused person would be so reckless as to continue to wear a blood stained pyjama after having perpetrated the crime.

Judged by this standard, which it was open to them to prescribe, it seems to us that the case of each of the appellants clearly fell within the rule which they had laid down for their own guidance. The comment of the learned counsel for the appellants with regard to the blood-stained pyjama which was recovered from Massa Singh was, firstly, that it was not possible to gather from the evidence the extent of the blood stains, and secondly that it would be highly improbable that this ac- cused person would be so reckless as to continue to wear a blood stained pyjama after having perpetrated the crime.
